result.execSummary:
The defendant Andrew J Emerson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Manufacture/Deliver Heroin (<3g), a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1)(d)1.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: Maintain FTW/School or combination of the two, or 10 hours community service if not fully engaged.

Assessment, treatment, and counseling as deemed appropriate by agent. 
DNA sample w/ surcharge.

If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  

A copy of the police report has been electronically sent to the probation office.

State appears by ADA Kyle Mayo.  Defendant appears in person with Atty Robin Kennedy.  Date and time set for Preliminary Hearing. Waiver of  Prelim filed.  COURT questions deft re: waiver.   COURT finds waiver freely & vol. made.   COURT finds probable cause & BOT.  Information filed. Waive reading.  Plea:  NG.  PTC: 5/5/15 at 2:20 pm.  Atty Kennedy informs Court defendant is waiting to get in rehab, and requests when he is in rehab that he be excused from participating in Attic.  COURT allows defendant not to comply with Attic while in rehab, and amends bond.
